ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I improved my writing and gained a more in-depth understanding of the history of reparations efforts in the US.
We learned about both the history and philosophy of reparations, and discussed at length the intersection of those areas. It was great to have a philosophy course that really felt practical.
Reading and analyzing philosophical works, applying them to tangible solutions
In-depth knowledge of philosophy and history related to anti-Black racism in the US, slavery, the history of racial discrimination, and the significance of reparations.

Knowledge: philosophies of justice, reparations frameworks, AfAm history 
Skills: talking about philosophy, arguing your own point of view, writing philosophy papers
I learned about the history of the legacy and practice of slavery and ethical theories about how to address it today.

A really comprehensive overview of everything that goes into reparations discussions  ethical theories, American history, current debates, etc. Intellectually, this may be the most important class that I've taken over my last three years here.

I gained knowledge about the philosophy of race/racism, various philosophical theories on justice and repair, some historical background of harm done against Black Americans, and proposals for reparations for slavery. Importantly, I was challenged to apply philosophy to a real-world issue, which is a unique task within the philosophy department.

Learned a lot about the evolution of racism and racist institutions in the United States. Prof did a good job of choosing readings that walked us through the evolution of slavery to convict leasing and share cropping to red lining and mass incarceration.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The readings were often long and boring, but class discussions were great. All of the students in my class were really engaged, and prof Darwall inserted valuable comments without taking up all of the space. The papers were pretty difficult to write, since prompts were very vague, and the syllabus changed a few times to alter paper lengths and due dates, which was frustrating.

Strengths include Professor Darwall, who is openminded and designs a great (if long) selection of readings. Classroom discussions were engaging, and he did a good job of getting everyone air time despite a large class. His feedback on essays is helpful, and he's extremely open to talking outside of class. 

I think there were two weaknesses with the course. One was the fact that there was just so much reading, it felt like we were never quite giving anything its fair time. The second is that the syllabus didn't have any critical race theory on it. We talked a lot about how racism and other problems still exist in present day America. I don't know why we couldn't have done that by reading about structural racism. I think that would be a great addition to the course.
I think the course could benefit from more student discussion or maybe a smaller group? I felt like we did not hear as many voices as wouldve been productive.

Its an absolutely incredible course that everyone should take. The only weakness was that often there was an unrealistic amount of weekly reading, so most people did a lot of skimming. But the course itself was fantastic.

Strengths: interesting and relevant readings, engaging seminar discussions, tying the material to current events, amazing professor 
Weaknesses: none

The course has excellent material and discussion. I wish it were smaller, more like 12-14 people, as the classes were not very long, and getting to everyone sometimes meant a cursory discussion of interesting material. Also the readings in the couple weeks were not as differentiated as throughout the rest of the course. Overall, excellent readings.

This is my favorite course I have taken! Class discussion was always really engaging  Professor Darwall bases it off of the readings and your responses to them, so it felt very student-driven, with a lot of buy-in from everyone in the seminar. I cannot recommend this course more than I do.

This class is exceptional.  Professor Darwall is a fantastic professor who creates a welcoming and engaging seminar environment.  He always has a great story to tell, but is so passionate about knowledgeable about the material.  I would take anything he's teaching in the future just to be in another class with him.  Additionally, the class effectively combines history, philosophy, and politics, allowing students to draw from a wide range of experiences and perspectives to better understand how we can go about conceptualizing a just scheme of reparations.  

No weaknesses.

This course was fantastic. The readings that Professor Darwall chose were all incredibly meaningful, and the way that class discussion was facilitated through student posts on Canvas kept things engaging. One weakness, I think, is that the reading could get to be very long (sometimes even 300 pages a week). This made it difficult to fully enjoy and absorb the information from the texts, since skimming was an inevitable necessity.

Strengths - how much you learn about racism in America and it's evolution. 
Weakness - too much reading, and I think the beginning philosophy readings were bad? I think there are many more modern and interesting philosophy we could be reading to give context to the issue of slavery than the ones that the prof chose.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course, but I'd caution another student that the course is a lot of work and papers are especially difficult to write.

Yes! It's pretty rare to take a philosophy course that so directly engages with practical problems. I'd take any class with him, including this one. It's also a great "intermediate" philosophy course. It's one of the few 400-levels that isn't cross-listed with the grad school, so it's a great way to transition from easier classes to really difficult ones.
Could not recommend it more

If you have the chance to take this course you definitely should. Professor Darwall is an absolutely amazing professor and all of the course materials were so eye-opening and engaging. I truly do not think I have taken a better course in my time at Yale, if any course could be required by the school it should be this one
Yes, but make sure you are interested in the subject matter.
I would absolutely recommend it for someone who wants to read, write, and talk. There is a lot of all of those things in the course.
10000%! If I could recommend this course to everyone, I could (and I will). If you're even moderately interested in the topic, definitely at least shop it.

Yes, absolutely!  Take the class for Darwall alone, and the actual content of the class is amazing.  I've learned so much and our class discussions were always engaging and exciting.  Could not recommend more!

Absolutely, this is the best course I have taken at Yale. It is such a special opportunity to apply philosophy to such a pressing, real-world issue and I would make the same decision to take the class over and over again.

yes if you're prepared to do a lot of reading and really engage! because it is so much content, you're only gonna enjoy it if you dig into it. if you only half go into it, it just kind of goes over your head.
